FacilityName: San Francisco Refinery at Rodeo, California

No other substances at the refinery are included in the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Title 40, Parts 9 and 68, Tables 1 and 2, or California's 19 CCR, Chapter 4, Table 3 List of Regulated Substances. 
The maximum inventories of applicable RMP chemicals stored at the SFR are provided in Appendix A. Per 19 CCR 2770.2, only streams containing one percent or greater of a regulated toxic or flammable materials are included in the reported maximum inventories. Toxic mixtures with a partial pressure of the regulated substance below 10 millimeters of mercury are not included in the inventories. This is true for many of the amine solutions present throughout the refinery, designed to capture hydrogen sulfide for treatment in the Sulfur Complex. For toxic mixtures, only the weight of the regulated substance is reported. For flammable mixtures, the entire weight of the mixture is treated as the regulated substance, per 19 CCR 2770.2(b)(2). However, flammable mixtures that do not have a National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) flammability hazard rating of 4 are not covered under RMP.  For the purpose of this RMP a conservative assumption was made that any stream containing 20% or greater of C1-C5 hydrocarbons is NFPA 4.
Covered Processes
This RMP divides the refinery into several processes based on the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) definition of a process. This is based on the USEPA's intent to have RMP be consistent with OSHA's interpretation of a process as defined in OSHA's PSM rule, as stated in the preamble to the June 20, 1996, RMP rule (61 Federal Regulation 31668).. Under OSHA PSM, essentially each unit is a process, with the exceptions of Units 229, 230 and 231, which are grouped as th

or elements of the RMP. Policy 5.0-1, Refinery Process Safety Management Program & HSE Management System Element Cross-Reference, describes how the RMP elements fit into the HSEMS.  
The Element Owner conducts an annual evaluation following the HSEMS Excellence Assessment Process model to assess performance levels and identify areas for improvement. Each Element Owner, working with a team of employees, develops annual improvement goals. Goals are based on the HSEMS Standard, the annual review, audit findings, employee suggestions, incident statistics, leading metrics, incident investigations, best practices, and other sources. The HSE Manager and the Refinery Leadership Team develop strategic HSE goals for inclusion in the annual Business Planning process. 
Similarly, the RMP elements are assigned Element Owners as follows: 
¿	The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) coordinator is responsible for PHA, Management of Change (MOC) and Pre Start-Up Safety Review (PSSR) program elements. 
¿	The Process Engineering supervisor is responsible for the Process Safety Information (PSI) program element. 
¿	Personnel in the Health and Safety Department have responsibility for Hot Work, Contractors, Incident Investigation, Compliance Audits, Emergency Response, Employee Participation, and Training. 
¿	Training for Operators and Operating Procedures are the responsibility of the Operations Department. 
¿	Training for maintenance employees is the responsibility of the Maintenance Department. 
¿	Mechanical Integrity is jointly owned between Technical Services and Maintenance Departments. 

The SFR's Policies and Procedures Manual contains all the policies pertaining to safety and environmental performance and is available to employees on the SFR's intranet, as well as in hard copy in central locations at the refinery. Senior Management is ultimately responsible for the Policies and Procedures Manual. The manual contains Emergency Response Policies, which establish a management s

ludes procedures for the use of emergency response equipment, and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance. The ERP also discusses emergency procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases and addresses emergency medical treatment.
The Field Safety and Emergency Response Superintendent is responsible maintaining the ERP. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The facility is committed to ensuring its operations are safe and in accordance with all RMP requirements. To ensure that appropriate changes are implemented as necessary to maintain and improve safety, ongoing PHAs, training, reviews and updates of operating procedures, audits, maintenance, and investigations will be conducted as required by the RMP. 
The SFR has implemented and plans to implement additional improvements to meet new company standards for Safety Instrumented Systems, Emergency Isolation Valves, and others.  These company standards often exceed industry standards.  The SFR identifies ways to improve safety through a number of avenues, which include PHAs, audits, incident investigations, employee suggestions, and the preventative maintenance program.  Recommended changes are evaluated for implementation to improve the overall safety of the facility.  The SFR plans to complete many enhancements to improve safety. Some of these include:
¿	The Controls Modernization project which brings all of the board Operators in the refinery into one central location in order to improve safety of Operators, communications, and response to changing conditions in the refinery.  This project included the installation of many new automatic safety systems to ensure the unit operating parameters stay inside the safe design limits without human intervention.  Safety Integrity Level evaluations are incorporated into these modernizations;
¿	Propane Recovery System - to recover propane from refinery fuel gas and Hydrogen Plant feed gas.  This project will reduce

and policies for addressing these areas. 
The Release Prevention Program Elements are a part of the overall safety program at the refinery. The SFR uses a Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) Management System (HSEMS) to coordinate the programs as required by the Phillips 66 corporate standard. The objective of the SFR HSEMS is to ensure that business activities are conducted in a safe and environmentally responsible manner through the implementation of the HSE policies and the Phillips 66 HSEMS Standard. This objective is achieved by providing organizational structure, programs, procedures, processes, and resources to manage the business activities safely and with respect and care for the environment. The HSEMS seeks to:
¿	Demonstrate management commitment to health, safety, and environmental stewardship.
¿	Ensure that all reasonably practicable steps are taken to identify the hazards and risks arising from our business activities.
¿	Establish adequate control over business activities with the aim of achieving safe, incident- and injury-free working conditions.
¿	Maximize operational integrity, reliability, and efficiency.
¿	Ensure regulatory compliance.
¿	Promote high standards and the continuous improvement of our HSE performance.

The HSEMS system is described in the SFR HSEMS Program Description document available to all employees via the company intranet (Connect66). The document provides a description of the programs, procedures, and processes that are in place at the SFR to implement the Phillips 66 Company and SFR's HSE policies. The corporate HSEMS Standard describes a five-phase continuous improvement cycle of Policy and Leadership, Plan, Do, Assess, and Adjust built around 15 management system elements.  Each management system element is assigned to an Element Owner, who has the responsibility for its implementation. Senior Management has the overall responsibility for the HSEMS. Many of the elements, such as Asset & Operations Integrity, mirr

flaring by improving the fuel gas balance in the refinery, adding an additional margin of safety when units have an upset condition and shutdown.  This will also result in a significant reduction in the refinery's sulfur dioxide emissions to the atmosphere;
¿	Perform engineering design review of all sour water sources to minimize or eliminate light hydrocarbons from these utility process streams, similar to the events that led to the Tank 294 incident.

Action items for improving safety are tracked using the SFR's IMPACT database.
In addition, the refinery continuously seeks and evaluates methods to improve the safety of its operations. Recommendations from audits, incident investigations, PHAs, equipment tests and inspections, and employee suggestions provide opportunities to enhance the safety of the refinery. The Metallurgical Engineering and Inspection (ME&I) Department has well established inspection programs for piping, vessels and tanks that are consistent with American Petroleum Institute (API) Inspection Codes, CCR Petroleum Safety Orders, and company Inspection Best Practices. ME&I maintains a risk-prioritized list of findings from regulatory required and company recommended inspections. These findings are assigned to the responsible department for correction, and followed up on for completion.
Improvements in technology provide another opportunity to enhance facility safety. Inherently Safer Systems are actively studied as a part of all new project implementation work. Improving safety at the SFR is an ongoing activity.

fide and ammonia, which are processed elsewhere. These units also saturate olefins. These units are particularly important for ensuring cleaner burning fuels, since the removal of these compounds is critical to preventing smog from engine combustion of gasoline and diesel. The Unisar Unit (Unit 248) removes aromatic compounds from its feedstock by saturating these compounds. The Unisar Unit produces finished aviation jet fuel. The reformer units (Unit 231 Reforming and Unit 244 Reformer) rearrange hydrocarbons from straight chains into branched chains and rings. The Isomerization Unit 228 also rearranges straight chains into branched chains. Branched chains and ringed compounds are desirable because they raise the octane number of the motor fuels. 
The cracking processes produce very small hydrocarbons as well as the larger fractions discussed above. Units like the Gasoline Fractionation Unit (Unit 215) separate these small molecules. The smallest molecules (one, two, and three carbons) are used in the refinery for fuel. Butanes are produced for commercial sale. 
The refinery has a Steam Power Plant that produces electricity as well as high pressure, high temperature steam, which is used for both heating and cooling various processes. The Steam Power Plant's demineralizer produces high quality water for use in the plant and process cooling systems. The Waste Water Treatment Plant (Unit 100) is the refinery's waste water treatment system. The water that is removed from crude oil prior to processing and water from other process stages, including stripped sour water, is treated by biological systems and carbon filtration prior to its permitted discharge. In addition, selenium is removed by the Selenium Removal Plant.
The sulfur and nitrogen removed from processing streams is sent to the Sulfur Complex (Units 235, 236, and 238). The Sulfur Complex converts the sulfur in the streams (as hydrogen sulfide) into elemental sulfur. The elemental sulfur is sold to agricultu

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The Phillips 66 Company (Phillips 66) San Francisco Refinery at Rodeo (SFR or refinery) is located in unincorporated Contra Costa County, near the town of Rodeo, California. The SFR encompasses a total of 1,100 acres of land, consisting of the 495-acre active area of the refinery, where all its facilities and equipment are located, and another 600 acres of undeveloped areas. The SFR consists of refining processes and support units that produce fuels, sulfur, and petroleum coke. The refinery's principal activity is fuels manufacturing, wherein the facility converts crude oil and other feedstock into gasoline, jet fuel, diesel, and industrial fuels. Numerous chemicals, materials, and utilities are required to produce useful products from the crude oil. 
The SFR is subject to RMP requirements because it stores and uses regulated substances in quantities exceeding the regulated thresholds. The refinery uses flammables, hydrogen sulfide (H2S), and aqueous ammonia (NH3) in quantities that exceed their respective state RMP thresholds. The purpose of the RMP program is to prevent accidental releases of regulated substances and minimize the severity of those releases if they should occur. 
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The SFR's Commitment to Responsible Business Policy best depicts the mission and vision set forth for the refinery. The Policy emphas the commitment to operate and maintain the facility and equipment in a manner that promotes (1) the health, safety, and security of employees, neighbors, and the public and (2) the responsible use of resources and care of the environment. The refinery's mission statement also includes a safe work environment for employees. 
The SFR has a policy advocating a safe workplace and sound environmental operations. Phillips 66 places primary responsibility for health, safety, and the environment within each of the major facilities. Each major facility has comprehensive programs

tandard for reporting emergencies, response to emergencies, and individual employee actions during emergencies. 
FACILITY OVERVIEW AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Phillips 66 SFR is located in unincorporated Contra Costa County, near the town of Rodeo. The refinery encompasses a total of 1,100 acres of land, consisting of the 495-acre active area of the refinery, where all its facilities and equipment are located, and another 600 acres of undeveloped areas. It is bordered by the NuStar Terminal to the north, and an undeveloped area to the east. To the south is a 300- to 600-foot undeveloped area (property maintained as buffer areas between the active or developed portion of the refinery and adjacent land uses), beyond which is the Bayo Vista residential area. San Pablo Bay borders the refinery to the west.
Interstate Highway 80 and San Pablo Avenue run north-south through the refinery property. The property is zoned as heavy industrial. Land uses to the northeast of the refinery are a combination of industrial and open space. To the east is primarily open space, and a combination of residential, light commercial, and light industrial uses are found to the south and southwest. The nearest sensitive receptor is a day-care facility in the Bayo Vista residential area, near the southern property boundary, south of the undeveloped buffer zone. 
The refinery consists of refining processes and support units that produce fuels, sulfur, and petroleum coke. The refinery's principal activity is fuels manufacturing, wherein the facility converts crude oil and other feedstock into gasoline, jet fuel, diesel, and industrial fuels. The SFR processes approximately 76,000 barrels (one barrel equals 42 gallons) of crude oil and approximately 38,000 barrels of partially refined oil from the Santa Maria Refinery per day into transportation fuels. The principal fuels produced are gasoline, diesel, and jet fuels. The refinery also produces butane and elemental sulfur for commer

ral markets.
Description of Regulated Substances
Most of the substances handled at the refinery regulated by the RMP are flammables. These materials range in flammability from pentane (with a flash point greater than -40 F) to hydrogen (with a flash point of -100 F). Higher flash points indicate less flammability. Materials with low flash points must be handled carefully and isolated from ignition sources to prevent fires or explosions. For comparison, gasoline has a flash point of -45 F and diesel fuel has a flash point of 125 F. 
As part of refining crude oil to motor fuels, some regulated toxic substances are generated in addition to the flammables. Hydrogen sulfide and aqueous ammonia are present at the refinery at quantities exceeding their regulatory limits. Hydrogen sulfide, with its characteristic rotten egg odor, is created in the processing units that remove sulfur and nitrogen from the refining streams. It is a colorless, corrosive, toxic gas and its odor can be readily detected at concentrations below concern. Hydrogen sulfide is not stored at the refinery. As soon as it is generated, it is immediately sent to the Sulfur Complex for processing. In addition, minor amounts of hydrogen sulfide may evolve from spills of sour water. Ammonia is also created and treated by the same processing units. Ammonia is a colorless, corrosive, toxic gas with a sharp irritating odor. Its odor is also readily detectable at concentrations below concern. The SFR uses aqueous ammonia for nitrogen oxide emission control. Hydrogen sulfide and ammonia are hazardous principally through inhalation. 
There are several other regulated substances present at the refinery at quantities below their regulatory thresholds, and thus not subject to RMP requirements. These chemicals include carbon disulfide, hydrochloric acid, vanadium pentoxide, and cyclohexylamine. In addition, the sulfuric acid stored and used in the refinery is not subject to RMP requirements because it does not meet

cial purposes. In addition, the refinery produces petroleum coke.  
The SFR is designed and operated to refine a variety of domestic and foreign crude oils, such as heavy crudes from Central California and Canada, as well as medium crude oils, such as Alaskan North Slope and Escalante. The SFR processes San Joaquin Valley Crudes diluted with feedstock produced by the Santa Maria Refinery. San Joaquin Valley Crudes are heavy oils, rich in sulfur and nitrogen. This heavy oil must be converted to lighter hydrocarbons in order for it to be useable as motor fuels. In addition, the sulfur and nitrogen must be removed from the oil distillates during processing to produce motor fuels that produce less smog upon combustion by cars and trucks. The refinery also processes lighter, sweeter crudes from overseas. Crude oil is brought to the refinery via pipeline and marine tanker. Tankers dock at the refinery's Marine Terminal, located at the northwestern edge of the facility.
Numerous chemicals, materials, and utilities are required to produce useful products from the crude oil. Some chemicals, such as hydrogen, are produced at the SFR or supplied by Air Liquide, which operates a hydrogen Production Plant adjacent to the refinery. Other feedstock, chemicals, and materials are purchased and transported to the facility. The refinery generates its own steam, fuel gas, and electricity, and purchases other resources, such as natural gas and water. 
The refinery accomplishes the production of these products from crude oil through the use of many complex processing units. Appendix B includes an overall block flow diagram showing the refinery's existing production processes. Crude oil is sent to distillation units to make the first separation of crude oil into its various components. Additional processing takes place in a number of refinery units including coking, isomerization, hydrocracking, reforming, and blending units. The following discussion describes the SFR's existing proces

ses.
The SFR has two crude processing units. Unit 267 is a Crude Distillation Unit that processes light, sweet crude oil from overseas. Processing begins in the Desalter, where the oil is dehydrated and salts are removed electrically to reduce the corrosivity of the oil. Following desalting, it is sent to a distillation tower where the hydrocarbons are heated and separated into fractions by molecular weight. Lighter hydrocarbons have lower boiling points than heavier hydrocarbons. Unit 267 produces six different fractions: vent gas, light naphtha, medium naphtha, light diesel, heavy diesel, and vacuum resid. The second crude unit is associated with the Coker (Unit 200). It processes diluted San Joaquin Valley Crude into three fractions: naphtha, gas oil, and vacuum resid. The heaviest fraction, resid, is composed of very heavy hydrocarbons and is a solid at ambient temperatures. This material is sent to the Coker, where the large molecules are thermally cracked into smaller ones. These smaller molecules can then be further processed into motor fuels. The Coker also produces petroleum coke, which is shipped offsite.
The gas oil fractions from the crude units and the Coker are still too large for use as motor fuels. These fractions are catalytically cracked in the Unicracker Unit (Unit 240) and the heavy gas oil Hydrocracker Unit (Unit 246). These units crack the hydrocarbon molecules into smaller molecules in the presence of hydrogen and a catalyst. Hydrocracking is more selective than thermal cracking. Olefins and other unsaturated compounds are saturated during this hydrocracking process in addition to breaking larger chain or ringed hydrocarbons into smaller compounds. Olefins are undesirable in motor fuels because they contribute to the formation of smog during engine combustion; therefore, they must be removed.
The diesel and naphtha hydrotreating units (Unit 250, Unit 2290, and Unit 230) remove sulfur and nitrogen from their feedstocks, creating hydrogen sul

e MP-30 Complex; Units 234 (out of service), 235, 236, and 238, which are grouped as the Sulfur Complex; and the four plants (Plants 1, 2, 3, and 4) of Unit 240, which are grouped as Unit 240 (Unicracker).
For processes that exceed the maximum intended inventory thresholds for regulated substances, the RMP defines three program levels, each with its own requirements. The applicable program level is dependent upon the complexity, accident history, and potential impact of releases of regulated substances. The applicability requirements are as follows:
¿	Program 1
o	For the 5 years prior to submission of an RMP, the process has not had an accidental release of a regulated substance where exposure to the substance, its reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance has led to offsite death(s), offsite injury(ies), or response or restoration activities for an offsite exposure of an environmental receptor;
o	The distance to a toxic or flammable endpoint for a worst-case release assessment is less than the distance to any public receptor; and
o	Emergency response procedures have been coordinated between the stationary source and local emergency planning and response organizations.
¿	Program 2
o	The covered process does not meet the eligibility requirements of Program 1 or Program 3.
¿	Program 3
o	The process is in certain predefined North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) Code categories;
o	The process is subject to the federal or state OSHA PSM standards; or
o	The administering agency determines that the accident risk posed by the regulated substance in a process above the threshold quantity as listed in 19 CCR 2770.5, because of the nature and quantity of the regulated substance involved, requires the additional safety measures afforded by Program 3 requirements.
The SFR has both Program Level 1 and Program Level 3 processes. The covered processes for

the SFR are:
PROGRAM LEVEL 1:
¿	Isomerization Unit (Unit 228)
¿	MP30 Complex (Units 229, 230, 231)
¿	Diesel Hydrotreater (Unit 250)
PROGRAM LEVEL 3:
¿	Butane Systems
¿	Steam Power Plant (NOx Controls)
¿	Coker (Unit 200)
¿	Gasoline Fractionation (Unit 215)
¿	Fuel Gas Center (Unit 233)
¿	Unicracker (Unit 240)
¿	Reforming Unit (Unit 244)
¿	Heavy Hydrocracker (Unit 246)
¿	Crude Unit (Unit 267)

OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

The Chemical Safety Information, Site Security and Fuels Regulatory Relief Act restricts the distribution of offsite consequence analysis (OCA) information for security purposes. For this reason, the OCA for the SFR is not included here. The OCA for the SFR may be requested from the CUPA or USEPA.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM/POLICIES AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The RMP for the hazardous substances regulated by federal RMP regulations have been developed and implemented to enhance employee and public safety. 
Management Systems
The SFR has implemented a management system for developing and continually improving the RMP elements. The Health, Safety & Environmental Manager has the overall responsibility for the management of the RMP. The facility has developed a PSM/RMP Compliance Audit program (Policy 14.0-6) to help ensure compliance with the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP) and federal RMP programs, as well as the state and federal PSM programs. The California OSHA (Cal-OSHA) PSM regulation addresses process safety at industrial facilities. CalARP and PSM regulations are similar in their requirements. 
While Senior Management has overall responsibility for the management of the risk management elements, personnel who have the responsibility for the elements periodically evaluate the effectiveness of their program, through internal audits, and make changes as the need arises. Senior Staff also periodically review each program for effectiveness. Senior Management sets goa

HISTORY
The RMP regulation requires a listing of accidents for the past 5 years from covered processes that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. The SFR has had one accident involving a covered process that met these criteria in the last 5 years. 
On June 15, 2012, an over-pressure occurred on Tank 294 causing an approximately 20-foot separation in the roof-shell seam, resulting in the release of a combination of the natural gas blanket, hydrocarbons and hydrogen sulfide vapors. The overpressure was caused by a large volume of light hydrocarbons being directed to Tank 294 due to flow reversal in the line between Tank 267 and Tank 294.
Phillips 66 promptly initiated its emergency response procedures, which included emergency response team members responding directly to Tank 294 and activation of the Refinery Incident Management Team and Emergency Operations Center. The Community Warning System (CWS) was activated promptly and all required agencies were notified. Representatives from the Contra Costa County Health Services (CCCHS) Hazardous Materials (Hazmat) Division and the Bay Area Air Quality Management District (BAAQMD) responded to the incident and participated in strategic decisions made to manage the incident.
Throughout the day on June 15 and 16, numerous actions were taken to mitigate the release and reduce odors. Representatives from the refinery Health & Safety Department conducted offsite monitoring using a RAE Systems Multi-RAE 5-gas meters. Additional measurements were taken by BAAQMD and CCCHS-Hazmat Division. Odors were detected in the surrounding community; however measured levels of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) were below 2.0 ppm and hydrogen sulfide were below the toxic endpoint (TEP) of 30 parts per million (ppm). No injuries occurred as a result of the incident.
At 8:30 a.m. on June 17, 201

2, the Incident was downgraded to a CWS Level-0 and emergency response operations were suspended. The release duration was approximately 40 hours. It is estimated that approximately 42 pounds of hydrogen sulfide was released during that time.
No other accidents from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage have occurred in the past 5 years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The emergency response program is described in a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP), which consists of organization, procedures, and equipment for an emergency response. This program addresses emergency responses for fires, explosions, releases of hazardous materials and medical emergencies. The ERP addresses coordination with local agencies and the public. 
The ERP has been prepared in coordination with the local emergency response area plan (the Contra Costa County Hazardous Materials Area Plan).  In addition, the ERP contains a number of annexes, including the SFR Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan and the Spill Prevention, Control, and Countermeasures Plan. The ERP is revised at least annually; however, it may be revised more frequently if any of following activities indicate the need for a change: applicable federal, state or local regulatory changes, the ERP fails in an emergency, significant changes in facility operation occurs, the emergency contact list changes, changes occur in emergency response equipment or procedures, or a review reveals a deficiency in the ERP. 
The ERP is an important resource tool that includes sections on the Incident Command System, roles and responsibilities, alarm and notification systems, response procedures for specific emergencies, internal and external resources, training and drill requirements, medical surveillance for emergency responders and ERP review and updating procedures. The plan also inc
